Award.AwardTitle: Microfluidic Devices for Tunable RF Communication Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Reconfigurable RF antennas and circuits have been implemented in several ways including the use of MEMS switches, variable impedance elements, or manipulation of the ground plane. No single solution achieves all the desired qualities of low loss, agility, low cost, and reliability. A new approach is proposed that involves liquid-metal microfluidic technology for geometrically reconfiguring antennas and circuits by literally moving metal across a planar surface. The aim is to use microfluidic actuation of liquid metals to make the tuning of RF devices as straightforward as drawing patterns using an Etch-A-Sketch toy. The proposed approach will replace typical copper microstrip components with a metal that is liquid at room temperature, such as mercury or gallium alloys. These liquid metals can reflow to form conductive elements of varying shapes and sizes, resulting in a tuning of the RF circuit. Microfluidic technology provides precise control of small liquid volumes, and has been widely developed for applications such as biomedical devices. The functionality of microfluidics will be extended to include tunable RF devices. To maximize flexibility and speed of fluidic actuation while minimizing interference with RF components, fluid actuation using electrowetting and pressure-driven flow will be used to create tunable RF devices using liquid metals.

Intellectual Merit
The research objective of this proposal is to use microfluidic actuation to enable the tuning of RF devices using dynamic, flexible patterning of liquid metal RF elements. Using a 2D embedded electrode array or specially designed microchannels, it will be possible to dynamically pattern liquid metals in all types of shapes and sizes. The proposed approach can be used for geometrically reconfiguring planar transmission line elements that form the basis of antennas, filters, matching networks, and coupling structures. In this proposal, the capabilities of liquid-metal patterning will be demonstrated by creating tunable reflectarrays for autonomous, high-directivity beamsteering and tunable frequency-selective surfaces for RF filters. Results of the proposed research will be valuable to RF system designers and the RF community.

Broader Impacts
The broader impacts of realizing such agile, reconfigurable components are huge, impacting commercial, scientific, government, and military applications. The proposed research will enable systems that are more versatile, multifunctional, robust, and economical. Recently a need has been identified for a widespread, affordable, and accessible broadband wireless networks as one of the key economic drivers for this nation, and the proposed research is a step towards realizing this goal. In addition, this proposal will strongly focus on the participation of underrepresented minorities in graduate- and undergraduate-level research projects. Native Hawaiian engineering students will be encouraged to participate as student researchers for the proposed research. Concepts related to the proposed research will be introduced in an engaging manner to pique interest in science and engineering among K-12 students via open houses and lectures at local schools.

Participants

PI: Aaron T. Ohta

Co-PI: Wayne Shiroma

Graduate students: Bao Jun Lei, Shuyan Guo, Wade Tonaki, Wenqi Hu, Ryan Gough, Andy Morishita, Jonathan Dang

Undergraduate students: Andy Morishita, Carolynn Kitamura, Kainalu Matthews, Melvin Visitacion, Kelson Lau, Julian Cheng, Clayton Chen, Matthew Inouye, Christopher Brough, Matthew Moorefield, Michael Dubiel

 

The major research objective of this project was to use liquid metals to create new types of devices and circuits for wireless communication systems. The vast majority of electronic circuits are designed under the assumption that the metal parts in the circuit cannot be changed after the circuit is built; the use of metals that are liquid at room temperature challenges that assumption, and gives circuit designers more flexibility. For example, liquid metal can be made to change its shape, enabling a liquid-metal device to operate at a different frequency. This can simplify radio electronics on phones, other mobile devices, aircraft, automobiles, ships, and many other platforms. This research showed that devices using liquid-metal can be used to create filters, tuners, antennas, baluns, and phase shifters that can be adjusted on the fly. Furthermore, methods were developed to move and shape liquid metal using electrical control, an important step towards making this technology commercially viable.

 

The major educational objectives of this project were the participation of underrepresented minorities in graduate- and undergraduate-level research projects, including Native Hawaiian engineering students, and introducing concepts related to the research among K-12 students via open houses and lectures at local schools. Seven graduate (3 PhD, 4 MS) and 11 undergraduate students participated in the research; of the undergraduate participants, 45% continued their education to pursue graduate degrees. Together with the faculty, the students co-authored 18 publications. Three Native Hawaiian students (including one who is a female) participated in this project. The graduate and undergraduate students involved with this project have showcased their results at the College of Engineering Open House and annual Banquet; both events were open to the public. Lab tours were also given annually to middle-school students, and researchers visited public schools to discuss this research and introduce engineering to middle school students.

 

Additional Information:

In part because of their participation on this research, students involved in this project received the following recognitions:

  • Andy Morishita was recognized as the Fall 2012 Outstanding Graduating Senior in Electrical Engineering. He became an MS student in Spring 2013, and graduated in Fall 2014. He was recognized with the 2014 College of Engineering Outstanding Graduate Research Award at the MS level. He also won an IEEE MTT-S Undergraduate/Pre-graduate Scholarship.
  • Jonathan Dang joined this project as an MS student in Fall 2013, and graduated in Spring 2015. He was recognized with the 2015 College of Engineering Outstanding Graduate Research Award at the MS level. He also won the IEEE Life Members Scholarship.
  • Ryan Gough entered the PhD program in Spring 2013.
